ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
The species is protected by sub-national and national legislation. It is listed on Appendix II of the Berne Convention, on Annexes II and IV of the EU Natural Habitats Directive, and on the national and sub-national Red Data Books. It is present in the protected areas of the Tramuntana Mountains.

The Balearic Government and the Jersey Wildlife Preservation Trust have undertaken captive-breeding, re-introduction and other conservation initiatives. At least ten subpopulations have been successfully reintroduced. Reintroductions of animals from the Jersey Wildlife Preservation Trust stopped in 2002, but a new captive-breeding facility now exists on Mallorca, and reintroductions continue. However, as a result of the recent discovery of disease, a recommendation was made in 2004 to the Balearic Government to halt the reintroduction programme. A new recovery programme for the species is now being developed. A systematic programme is in place to remove Natrix maura from the range of the species. Successful mitigation of chytridiomycosis took place after thousands of tadpoles were treated with fungicide in the laboratory and chemicals were applied into the environment (J. Bosch pers. comm. November 2019).

Conservation Needed
The threats are not likely to decrease, and so the current recovery programme needs to be continued more or less indefinitely. Recreational activities are not adequately regulated or controlled (Á. Román pers. comm. November 2019), thus this could be improved to benefit the conservation of the species.

Research Needed
There is a need for continual population monitoring of this species given the threats of invasive species and disease. An action plan for its recovery and management is needed.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative:
This species is currently found only in small streams deeply carved into limestone mountains. The presence of the species is positively associated with steep slopes. A few subpopulations occur by man-made water sources (cattle troughs, containers, rain tanks etc.) in open mountainous country; these are within the river basins of nearby canyon-living subpopulations. Animals are generally found in rock crevices and under stones. This species does not tolerate serious habitat degradation. The distribution of predators on the species is negatively associated with elevation, and reproductive success is positively associated with elevation.

Breeding takes place in the small streams that persist as pools in summer. Clutch size varies from 4-34 eggs (Pinya and Perez-Mellado 2014a). Females and males had a mean longevity of 4.70 years and 3.24 years, respectively, the maximum estimated longevity was 18 years for both sexes, males reached sexual maturity at the age of one year, and most females at two years (Pinya and Perez-Mellado 2014b). Survival was estimated as 0.737±0.042 and 0.726±0.045, for males and females, respectively (Pinya et al. 2017).
PopulationDocumentation.narrative:
The population is approximately 500-1,500 adult pairs (Gasc et al. 1997, Arnold 2003), however, the total population is slowly increasing following coordinated recovery efforts (establishment of reintroduced subpopulations) following a long period of decline and near extinction. Subpopulations are fragmented with low levels of gene flow (J. Bosch pers. comm. November 2019). There are approximately 25, mostly isolated, subpopulations. The current increase, which probably started around the time that the first reintroductions were made in 1989, has been maintained even during years of drought, notably in 1999-2000.

The population trend in this species is monitored through annual tadpole counts, the counts for 2004 (over 30,000 tadpoles) being the highest on record. The increase in numbers in established subpopulations is not dependent upon continued reintroductions. In general, the reintroduced subpopulations are successfully reproducing, although some receive new animals from time to time to reinforce them (J. Bosch pers. comm. November 2022). It is unlikely that new subpopulations would be established without reintroductions.
RangeDocumentation.narrative: This species is restricted to the Sierra Tramuntana of northern Mallorca, Balearic Islands, Spain, between 10-850 m asl (Doddington et al. 2013). Its area of occupancy (AOO) including successful reintroduction sites is uncertain but probably great than 50 km2 but certainly much less than 500 km2 (Doddington et al. 2013; J. Bosch pers. comm. November 2019, 2022). The AOO is slowly increasing as a result of intensive conservation action, including reintroduction sites. It occurs in fewer than five threat-defined but more than one threat-defined locations, and its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 519 km2.
RedListRationale.value: The Mallorcan Midwife Toad (Alytes muletensis) is endemic to Europe, where it is restricted to the Sierra Tramuntana of northern Mallorca, Spain. This species is listed as Endangered (EN B1ab(iii,v)+2ab(iii,v)) because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 519 km2, its area of occupancy is much less than 500 km2 (the threshold for the Endangered category), it occurs in five or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, and in the number of mature individuals due to disease and predation by invasive species.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
The major threats to this species are predation by the introduced Viperine Snake (Natrix maura), and competition for space with the introduced Perez's Frog (Rana perezi). There have been increased introductions of the Viperine Snake in Mallorca, and there have been 90% larval population declines observed in some sites (S. Pinya and Á. Román pers. comm. April 2020). Development of tourism and human settlements, specifically the increased need for water resources (including damming and canalisation of streams), is an additional threat, as is high human pressure on karstic creeks for recreational purposes, with the potential for the spread of disease agents (Á. Román pers. comm. November 2019). Chytridiomycosis was introduced in Mallorca through captive-bred individuals of this species, and it is considered to be a major threat (Bosch et al. 2015; J. Bosch pers. comm. November 2019), although the prevalence of Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd) has declined since the 2008 assessment (S. Pinya and Á. Román pers. comm. April 2020).

Captive-bred individuals are still being released, which poses the risk of introducing new diseases in wild subpopulations (Á. Román pers. comm. November 2019). Populations are currently in regression, with larvae abundances similar to 15 years ago (Cortes-Fernandez 2018).

Another problem is the lack of maintenance for newly created breeding habitats so, while this species has been reported from an increased number of new localities, the subpopulations are not persisting there over time (S. Pinya and Á. Román pers. comm. April 2020).
UseTradeDocumentation.value: There are no records of this species being utilised.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
Fourteen Natura 2000 protected areas list this species in their designations (EEA 2024), including Massif du Rotondo (FR9400578), Rivière et vallée du Fango (FR9400577), Lac de Créno (FR9402008), Massif du Renoso (FR9400611), Forêt de l'Ospedale (FR9400583), Massif du Tenda et forêt de Stella (FR9400598). It is listed on Appendix II of the Berne Convention and on Annexes II and IV of the EU Natural Habitats Directive, and is protected by national legislation in France.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: This frog is a stream specialist that occurs within a wide altitudinal range (Beukema and Bruni 2020), and is especially found in areas with precipitous streams. The eggs are presumably deposited in water bodies with little aquatic vegetation, like rocky pools and ponds in gravel beds, where the larvae also develop (Salvidio et al. 1999a,b; Emanueli et al. 2000).
PopulationDocumentation.narrative:
There is little information available on the population status of this species however, due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.

The species comprises at least three distinct evolutionary significant units that diverged during the Pleistocene (Bisconti et al. 2013).
RangeDocumentation.narrative: This species is endemic to Corsica, France (Gasc et al. 1997, Bisconti et al. 2013), where it is found mainly in the central part of the island, from Cap Corse and Calvi surroundings in the north to Porto-Vecchio in the south (Noellert and Noellert 1992, Beukema and Bruni 2020). It has been recorded from localities between 80 m asl and 1,900 m asl (Beukema and Bruni 2020), and is absent from eastern coastal lowlands. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 6,921 km².
RedListRationale.value: The Corsican Painted Frog is listed as Near Threatened since although its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 6,921 km<sup>2</sup>, the area of occupancy (AOO) is certainly below the 2,000 km<sup>2</sup> threshold for Vulnerable, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, thus making the species close to qualifying for Vulnerable under Criterion B. The species probably occurs in more than ten threat-defined locations based on hydrological impacts of climate change and dam construction and its population is probably not severely fragmented.
ThreatsDocumentation.value: A plausible threat to this species is the effect of flow regimes altered by dams, this is occurring throughout the range (R. Duguet pers. comm. March 2020). The decreased stream flow and reduced spring peak flow of rivers, caused by dams, could result in oviposition sites drying up before tadpoles complete metamorphosis (R. Duguet pers. comm. March 2020). The severity of this will be dependent on the climatic conditions of a particular year (R. Duguet pers. comm. March 2020). Climate change is a future threat for this species (R. Duguet pers. comm. March 2020).
UseTradeDocumentation.value: There are no records of this species being utilised.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is known to occur in Cabañeros and Doñana National Parks, in Spain, and is listed on Appendix II of the Bern Convention, and on Annex IV of the EU Habitats Directive. It is protected by national legislation in Spain and is recorded in a number of national and sub-national Red Data Books.

Conservation Needed
Further habitat protection is required, as is continued protection by existing protected areas.

Research Needed
Given the potential future threat of chytridiomycosis this species should be monitored closely.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: This species is closely associated with meadows and open oak (Quercus) forests, most often in sandy areas. It is not very adaptable. Reproduction and larval development generally takes place in temporary waterbodies (most often stream habitats), occasionally in permanent waterbodies; larval development is relatively long in this species and may last more than one season. Clutch size varies from 28-149 eggs (Pinya and Pérez-Mellado 2014).
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: This species can be locally common in suitable habitat, and is more abundant in the western part of its range. Population declines have been observed in Spain, potentially because of introduced predators. Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat and predation by invasive species, the population is suspected to be decreasing. On the contrary, potential distribution of predicted suitability by Maxent model suggest that climate change would contribute to population range increase (Rodriguez-Rodriguez et al. 2020).
RangeDocumentation.narrative: This species is restricted to southern and eastern Portugal and western and central Spain, from 100-1,300 m asl (Gasc et al. 1997, Pleguezuelos 1997, Pleguezuelos et al. 2002, Godinho et al. 1999, Arnold 2003, Malkmus 2004).
RedListRationale.value: This European endemic species, restricted to the Iberian Peninsula, is listed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
ThreatsDocumentation.value: The main threats are the loss of suitable Mediterranean forest habitat, the introduction of predatory fishes (Alvarez and Martin 2000) and Louisiana Crayfish (Procambarus clarkii), and the loss of suitable aquatic habitats through pollution, canal construction, dams, and urbanization. A potential future threat is chytridiomycosis, which has already affected the related Alytes obstetricans in Spain.
UseTradeDocumentation.value: There are no records of this species being utilised.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
The species is listed on Appendix II of the Berne Convention, and on Annex IV of the EU Natural Habitats Directive. It is protected by national legislation in Italy and was listed as Vulnerable (B2ab(iii)) on the Italian National Red List (Rondinini et al. 2022). The species was assessed as Least Concern for France (UICN France et al. 2015).

The species has been recorded from 47 Natura 2000 sites across its range (BISE 2024). These include Parc o Nazionale dell’Arcipelago Toscano (Giglio and Montecristo islands, where the latter is an integral natural reserve), Parco Nationale del’Arcipelago di La Maddalena and Parco Nazionale del Golfo di Orosei e del Gennargentu-Parco Regionale dei Sette Fratelli-Monte Genis, and in Port-Cros National Park in France.

Conservation Needed
Better protection of existing suitable of aquatic habitats and continuous monitoring of population and habitat trends, and disease risk.

Research Needed
Further investigations into the genetic diversity of this species are needed.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative:
The species inhabits a wide range of aquatic and terrestrial habitats, natural and artificial including still and slow-running water bodies in open or wooded (coniferous and broadleaf) areas and macchia; it also occurs in springs and may even occur in slightly brackish pools. The species can tolerate some habitat disturbance.

Eggs are deposited in stream pools, forest floor puddles, coastal marshes, wet meadows, drainage ditches, reservoirs, and garden ponds among others, and the larvae develop in streams.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative:
This species is still common in suitable habitats in both Sardinia and Corsica. Little is known about Tyrrhenian Sea island subpopulations, although it is possible that they are threatened due to their probable small size. Subpopulations on Port-Cros dramatically declined, at least since 2008, however, it is still being recorded there (R. Duguet pers. comm. March 2020). The cause of the declines observed on Port-Cros are not fully understood but are presumed to be caused by either Wild Boar (which have been established on the island since 2007-2008), a lack of oviposition site (induced by climate change), and/or a disease (R. Duguet pers. comm. March 2020).

Chytridiomycosis has been associated with unusual mortalities at three sites in northern Sardinia (Bielby et al. 2009). On the other hand, a recent survey on Levant showed that the species is still recorded in good numbers (R. Duguet pers. comm. March 2020, confirmed during review workshop 2022). Although Vignoli et al. (2017; D. Salvi and D. Canestrelli pers. comm.) noted that the species was still being recorded in good numbers throughout most of its Italian range, current information stemming from monitoring data shows that some subpopulations are in decline (C. Corti pers. comm. October 2022).
RangeDocumentation.narrative: The species is mainly restricted (Gasc et al. 1997, Arnold 2003) to the islands of Sardinia (Italy) and Corsica (France, where it is absent from the high mountains in the centre of the island; Salvidio and Delaugerre 2012, Corti et al. 2022), with other subpopulations occurring on a number of smaller Mediterranean islands in the Tyrrhenian Sea (Biaggini et al. 2015) including Caprera, La Maddalena, Spargi, San Pietro and Asinara, Montecristo and Giglio islands, Monte Argentario (fossil island), and also the islands of Port-Cros and Levant in the south of France (Port-Cros National Park; Deso et al. 2019, Duguet et al. 2019). The species was introduced into one locality of continental France (Bouches-du-Rhône Department, Provence) from Corsica (R. Duguet pers. comm. March 2020; not mapped). It has been recorded at elevations from sea level up to 1,770 m asl (Sardinia).
RedListRationale.value: This European endemic frog is assessed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
The species is still heavily threatened by environmental challenges, particularly in Sardinia, including the general loss of suitable woodland and aquatic habitats. Aquatic habitats used by this species are being lost through the damming of streams and increased water abstraction for tourism.

Chytridiomycosis and urbanisation also jeopardise this species (Bielby et al. 2009, C. Corti pers. comm. September 2019), with observed mortalities in three sites in the Limbara Mountains of northern Sardinia (D. Salvi pers. comm. Sept. 2022). However, since then, mortalities have not been observed in this species (L. Vignoli and D. Salvi pers. comm. Sept. 2022). The species was impacted by the chytrid fungus between 2006 and 2010; this led to the evaluation of VU national RL status in Italy in 2013 and recently (Rondinini et al. 2022). Ongoing analyses are showing that the species is still threatened by this pathogen (T. Kirschey pers. comm. October 2022), although overall this species does not appear to be significantly threatened by disease (D. Savi pers. comm. 2022). In France, introduced subpopulations in Var département are considered threatened and those in the Port-Cros National Park are threatened with extinction (Renet et al. 2020).

On Port-Cros and Levant one can suspect threats posed by predation by newly established Wild Boar populations and/or climate change deficit in groundwater recharge (R. Duguet pers. comm. March 2020). The introduction of Marsh Frogs (Pelophylax ridibundus) to Levant is also a potential threat to the subpopulations (R. Duguet pers. comm. March 2020). The study of Girardello et al. (2010) revealed that the distribution of D. sardus is largely determined by precipitation-related factors and in the future its overall area could shrink by one-third to one-fourth of the present one. Recent dynamics of dry seasons and more frequent fires cumulatively increase threat intensity on this species in Sardinia (C. Corti pers. comm. October 2022).
UseTradeDocumentation.value: There are no records of this species being utilised.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in many protected areas within its range. This species is listed on Appendix III of the Bern Convention.

Conservation Needed
Improved management is required of the protected areas and Natura 2000 sites that this species occurs in (Europe Red List Assessment Workshop September 2019).

Research Needed
Further research is required on its ecology, impacts of threats, distribution.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: This species is mostly aquatic and is commonly associated with still waters (lakes and pools), slow-moving rivers, canals, and marshes, often with rich vegetation at their edges. It is not known if the species can adapt to changes in habitat. Breeding and larval development takes place in these waterbodies.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: This species has been described as quite abundant throughout much of its range (Gasc et al. 1997) and it is considered to be common in Albania (Europe Red List Assessment Workshop September 2019). Some subpopulations are believed to be in decline due to the ongoing decline in the extent and quality of the habitat, the population is suspected to be decreasing.
RangeDocumentation.narrative:
The Epirus Water Frog is restricted to western Greece along the Ionian coast (including the island of Kerkyra; Valakos et al. 2008) and from the wetlands in the district Sarandë in south-western Albania (Jablonski 2011, Szabolcs et al. 2017), from sea level up to around 500 m asl. In mainland Greece, the Epirus Water Frog only occurs  west of the Pindos Mountain range and in the western Peloponnese, while its insular distribution is limited to Corfu, and reports from Zakynthos Island are doubtful and need confirmation (E.-A. Toli, Greece national Red List assessment). There are recent reports (Strachinis 2021) of individuals of the species east of the Pindos range and outside the currently accepted geographic range, however, a more comprehensive survey is required to determine if there is an established Epirus Water Frog population east of the Pindos Mountains.

The majority of its range is within Greece (Europe Red List Assessment Workshop September 2019). It seems likely that subpopulations of this species are fragmented because there are extensive areas of unsuitable habitat within its range. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 25,660 km2 globally. In the EU, the EOO is marginally smaller, at 25,439 km2. The area of occupancy AOO) has not been estimated globally due to the absence of georeferenced data for Albania. For the EU, the AOO from the Greece national Red List assessment (E.-A. Toli) is used here, 332 km2.
RedListRationale.value:
Global and European regional assessment: Near Threatened (NT)
EU 27 regional assessment: Vulnerable (VU)

This European endemic species is assessed as Near Threatened globally because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 25,660 km2, it occurs in ten or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, thus making the species close to qualifying for Vulnerable under criterion B. The area of occupancy (AOO) may be restricted at the global level, but this value has not been estimated due to the lack of georeferenced locality data for Albania, and the species should be reassessed if these data become available, as it is likely that the global is at the least, less than the threshold for Vulnerable.

The species is assessed as Vulnerable (2ab(iii)) under criterion B for the EU27 member states as the area of occupancy (AOO) is 332 km2 (E.-A. Toli, Greece national Red List assessment), it occurs in fewer than ten threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent of quality of its habitat.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
The species inhabits areas where human pressure is generally high (K. Sotiropoulos pers. comm. September 2019). The main threats to this species are the general loss of wetland habitat (through drainage for urbanisation, tourism, and agricultural intensification), and water pollution. Additionally, chemical pollution from agriculture intensification could be the cause of future declines of this species in Albania (Crnobrnja-Isailović et al. 2022). Dam construction and hydro-power developments are also considered to be major threats to this species (E. Mizsel pers. comm. September 2019).

A serious threat would be infection by the fungus Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd), which has been recently detected in Albania (Vojar et al. 2017), and in Greece, Bd has been detected in Epirus Water Frog, posing a significant threat to the species (Azmanis et al. 2016, Vojar et al. 2017, Strachinis et al. 2021). Climate change pose a future threat to the species due to the extensive droughts of suitable breeding sites. Another possible threat is genetic erosion through hybridisation with Pelophylax kurtmuelleri and Pelophylax ridibundus (Radojicic et al. 2015) since both species are largely sympatric. Climate change is a plausible future threat to this species.

It was previously reported in the 2008 assessment (Uzzell et al. 2009) and also in Haxhiu (2015) that the commercial collection of this species for food was a significant threat, and that it was harvested in enormous numbers in Albania. However there is no evidence that this species is collected excessively in Albania, and it is no longer considered to be a major threat (Europe Red List Assessment Workshop September 2019). However, there are continued reports of the collection of members of this genus in Albania, and miss-reporting of trade based on misidentification with other members of this genus is possible. The species is collected in Greece (Hatziioannou et al. 2022) and lacks specific law protection in Albania and Greece (D. Jablonski pers. data). The species is threatened by the large-commercial collecting for food in Greece which has been the main reason for the population decline in parts of its range (E.-A. Toli, Greece national Red List assessment).
UseTradeDocumentation.value: This species is utilised as food and is found in trade, however, this is not thought to be a major problem for this species and it is not a common practice (Europe Red List Assessment Workshop September 2019). However, Haxhiu (2015) mentioned that in Albania the exploitation of this species was so big that regulations and laws were needed to prohibit collection.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In Place
The species is present in the Lake Skadar protected area, on the border of Montenegro and Albania and coastal areas of Albania from Skadar to Orikum. It is listed on Appendix III of the Bern Convention. It is a protected species in Montenegro (Gvozdenović and Iković 2022) and considered Vulnerable in Albania (Anonymous 2013). It was under consideration for a CITES listing (Gratwicke et al. 2010), but this has not been successful to date.

Conservation Needed
Education on the disposal of waste for people living alongside the species, as well as the development of a harvest management plan will be beneficial for the conservation of this species (J. Crnobrnja-Isailović pers. comm. September 2019). Improved management of the protected areas is also recommended (J. Crnobrnja-Isailović pers. comm. September 2019).

Research Needed
Research on its population is required.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: This species has been reported from heavily vegetated aquatic habitats including ditches, swamps, marshes, the edges of slow-flowing rivers and the shoreline of Lake Skadar and coastal areas of Albania where is able to use partly brackish habitats. It is not known if the species can successfully adapt to habitat modification, however based on other species in the genus it is not likely to tolerate extensive threat to its water habitat (J. Crnobrnja-Isailović pers. comm. September 2019). Breeding and larval development take place in these wetland habitats.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative:
This species is considered to be quite rare (E. Mizsei pers. comm. September 2019) but it is very common in the places where it is present, often with P. ridibundus syntopically (J. Speybroeck pers. comm. October 2022).

Due to the decline in the extent and quality of habitat and over-collection for the pet trade, the population is suspected to be decreasing; a continuing decline in the number of mature individuals is inferred from the described threats. The species is considered to be severely fragmented due to the intense anthropogenic alteration of its wetland habitats, including drainage for illegal construction work or for sand extraction. It is not known if the species can successfully adapt to modified habitats, however, based on other species in the genus it is not likely to tolerate extensive changes to its wetland habitats (J. Crnobrnja-Isailović pers. comm. September 2019), and fragmentation is likely to lead to unviable fragmented subpopulations.
RangeDocumentation.narrative:
This lowland species is endemic to Europe, where it is restricted as native to western coastal Albania and southern Montenegro at elevations below 500 m asl. Recent records have expanded its range within these countries (see Jablonski 2011, Sillero et al. 2014, Iković et al. 2016, Szabolcs et al. 2017, Saçdanaku et al. 2020). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 10,387 km2.

There is evidence of its limited introduction to Umbria in Italy (Domeneghetti et al. 2013) and the possibility of introduction to Croatia (Koska 2016), although the latter requires confirmation and has been included in the distribution map but coded as 'Presence Uncertain'.
RedListRationale.value:
Global and European regional assessment: Vulnerable (VU)
EU 27 regional assessment: Not Applicable (NA)

The Albanian Water Frog (Pelophylax shqipericus) is endemic to the Balkan Peninsula, with a restricted distribution in coastal parts of Albania and southern Montenegro. It is assessed as Vulnerable because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 10,387 km2, its distribution is severely fragmented as a result of wetland habitat fragmentation, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat due to drainage of wetland habitats and aquatic pollution of waterways caused by agrochemical and industrial (including mining) contaminants. The Albanian Water Frog does not occur as native in the EU27 Member States and is therefore assessed as Not Applicable there.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
The major threat is the drainage and conversion of wetland habitats and the aquatic pollution of many waterways caused by agrochemical and industrial (including mining) contamination. Massive impacts, including illegal building (houses and hotels), excavation of sand, and solid waste disposal into water sources are widespread in Ulcinj, southernmost Montenegro (Polović and Čađenović 2014). Occurrence of B. dendrobatidis in Lake Skadar is another important threatening factor for this species, although it seems that it does not have a high impact on wild populations (Vojar et al. 2017). A review of potential threats is also presented in Crnobrnja-Isailović et al. (2018).

In the northern parts of its range (e.g., Lake Skadar) this species is significantly threatened by over-collection for commercial purposes for human consumption (Gratwicke et al. 2010, Haxhiu 2015, Auliya et al. 2023). The species is also collected for the international pet trade (Frank et al. 2018). An additional threat could be the accidental introduction of the commercially transported non-native water frog Aquarana catesbeianus, which may be competing with this species (J. Crnobrnja-Isailović pers. comm. September 2019). The species is collected for the food industry and by local people, even during the breeding season, for consumption in restaurants (Haxhiu 2015, Saçdanaku et al. 2020; D. Jablonski and E. Mizsei pers. obs.).

Albania represents the main distribution area for this endemic species. This species is distributed in a small range with a size of ~ 5,000 km2 (Jablonski et al. 2021) and most of the species' range is limited to populated coastal areas where massive development has occurred in the past years and the species might be threatened mainly by fragmentation and degradation of habitats. Moreover, the area is also the main agricultural region of Albania, and drainage, chemical, and waste pollution are important factors that will decrease the population of P. shqipericus (Haxhiu 2015, Saçdanaku et al. 2020, Crnobrnja-Isailović et al. 2022).
UseTradeDocumentation.value: This species is over-harvested for human consumption for both national and international purposes, and also collected for the international pet trade (Altherr et al. 2022).

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is listed on Appendix II of the Bern Convention and on Annex IV of the EU Natural Habitats Directive. The species is protected by regional legislation (Regional Law n. 23/1998 (art. 5, c. 3)). The Gola di Gorroppu has been designated as a Site of Community Importance under the Habitats Directive. In addition, a number of subpopulations live in established and planned protected areas, including Parco Regionale Sette Fratelli, Parco Nazionale Gennargentu-Golfo di Orosei, and Parco Regionale Monte Limbara.

The development of a citizen science project is also underway to help with the monitoring of amphibian species in Italy (F. Ficetola and R. Manenti pers. comm. September 2019). Furthermore, monitoring of all Natura 2000 sites and species is ongoing in Italy, including this species (F. Ficetola and R. Manenti pers. comm. September 2019). A reintroduction project is in place, where 30 individuals born in captivity at the Fondazione Bioparco di Roma as part of a project funded and sponsored by EAZA and Amphibian ARK (Tapley et al. 2015) were reintroduced in 2019 at a location in the Sette Fratelli (CA) area where the species was known until the late 1990s (L. Vignoli pers. comm. October 2022). The reintroduced individuals reproduced in 2020. All animals were screened for known diseases (F. Ficetola pers. comm. October 2022).

Conservation Needed
Programmes to monitor diseases, and remove trout and other alien species from the species' habitat would assist in the recovery of subpopulations (G. Tessa pers. comm. September 2019). There is also an urgent need for an EU (European Union) wide coordinated approach and implementation of the Bsal Action Plan by Gilbert et al. (2020), which was commissioned by the European Commission.

Research Needed
If an outbreak of Bsal was to occur within this species' range, population monitoring would need to be carried out immediately and this species would need to be reassessed. Long-term monitoring of subpopulations is necessary to avoid future population decline, particularly to set a baseline against potential disease introduction (F. Ficetola pers. comm. October 2022).
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: The Sardinian Brook Salamander is a montane species of permanent and temporary stagnant and running waters, that prefers calm areas of small or large rivers. Its terrestrial habitats are generally restricted to riverine scrub or woodland, and the species may also be found in cave systems. Its breeding sites are permanent pools, water holes, small lakes and streams. The eggs are deposited between stones or are buried in sand; the larvae develop in the streams (Griffiths 1996, Rimpp 1998). The species is quite adaptable and can be found in artificial pools.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative:
This is generally a rare species that can be locally common in suitable habitat (e.g. over 400 specimens may be found in a single pool). The largest subpopulation is in the Gola di Gorropu (eastern-central Sardinia). In one well-studied population, the sex ratio is largely male.

The number of subpopulations is in decline (Rondinini et al. 2013, 2022; NGO Zirichiltaggi Sardinia Wildlife Conservation 2022), and the recent increase of threats (from diseases and alien species) is causing a reduction in newt abundance, especially in small and suboptimal subpopulations (G. Tessa pers. comm. September 2019). The number of subpopulations was reported to be declining in 2008. Between 1999 and 2001 it was found in 14 sites, whereas previously around 1991 it was present in 30 sites (and even in 1991 it was absent from nine other sites where it had been previously observed). Sotgiu et al. (2010) and Vignoli et al. (2016) reported a number of subpopulations comparable with the subpopulations found by Alcher in the 1970s (Alcher 1975). Declines are thought to have occurred in the last 10 years due to the introduction of fish to streams and rivers, where this species occurs (Vignoli et al. 2016). A study on a recently detected new invasive crayfish species (Procambarus virginalis Lyko, 2017) in the freshwaters of Sardinia (Sanna et al. 2021) strongly supports the statement of conservationists that the rate of decline of the population of Sardinian Brook Salamander is increasing. However, it is not clear that there is a continuing decline in the number of mature individuals (Tessa et al. 2003; V. Ferri pers. comm. 2024).

In most of the territory it is fragmented, in some places more severely (V. Ferri pers. comm. 2024), and the species is considered here to be severely fragmented.
RangeDocumentation.narrative: This species is endemic to Sardinia, Italy (Gasc et al. 1997, Arnold 2003), where it is mostly found in the eastern part of the island between the Limbara Mountains in the north and the Sette Fratelli Mountains in the south. There are some historical records from western Sardinia (Lecis and Norris 2003a,b; Lecis and Norris 2014; Vignoli et al. 2016), however, there are no recent records from this part of southwestern Sardinia (Corti et al. submitted 2022; G. Sotgiu pers. comm. November 2022), and it is considered possibly extinct here. Further information is needed on the range of the species in the southwest of the island; there are anecdotal records from Iglesiente (Vignoli et al. 2016), but they have not been included in this assessment until further work has been carried out to verify that they belong to this species. It is not thought to occur much more widely. It has been recorded between 50–1,800 m asl, although it is most often found between 400–800 m asl. It occurs in five or fewer threat-defined locations, its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 10,609 km2, and its confirmed area of occupancy (AOO) (Vignoli et al. 2016) is less than 500 km2 (408 km2).
RedListRationale.value:
The Sardinian Brook Salamander (Euproctus platycephalus) is a European endemic species that is restricted to Sardinia (Italy). It is assessed as Endangered (B2ab(iii,iv)) as it has an area of occupancy (AOO) of 408 km2, and taking a precautionary approach, the species is estimated to occur in five or fewer threat-defined locations (based on invasive species and future disease threats), and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, and in the number of subpopulations. In addition, the species is considered to be severely fragmented.

Programmes to monitor novel diseases and remove alien invasive species from the species' habitat would assist in the recovery of subpopulations, and there is an urgent need for the EU-wide coordinated implementation of the Bsal Action Plan (Gilbert et al. 2020).
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
The major threats to the species are pollution of waterbodies, habitat fragmentation, predation by introduced trout, and prolonged drought (often caused by excessive water abstraction). During the 1950s, many subpopulations were lost through the application of DDT to waterbodies. The Gola di Gorroppu subpopulation and other streams in north and central Sardinia have become threatened through damage to its habitat caused by tourist activities, particularly hiking within the streams (C. Corti pers. comm. October 2022). Additional threats include Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd) with outbreaks detected from the north to the south of the island (Bovero et al. 2008, Bielby et al. 2013, Tessa et al. 2023), and the presence of the alien species of Green Frogs and the Red Swamp Crayfish Procambarus clarkii (Souty-Grosset et al. 2016, Oficialdegui et al. 2019; G. Tessa pers. comm. September 2019) and, the most recently, P. virginalis (Sanna et al. 2021). An increase in the number of alien species which have detrimental effects on local amphibian fauna (NGO Zirichiltaggi Sardinia Wildlife Conservation 2022) questions statements on the stability of subpopulations of E. platicephalus. Although already in a new dynamic balance for many decades, Natrix maura is also an important non-native predator for E. platycephalus (J. Speybroeck pers. comm. October 2022). The species is collected for the pet trade, which is thought to be slightly affecting the population.

Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans (Bsal) is an emerging fungal pathogen affecting amphibians and is closely related to B. dendrobatidis (Bd), which has had a devastating impact on amphibian populations around the world. Both pathogens cause the infectious disease chytridiomycosis, and both are believed to have originated in Asia (for Bsal: Martel et al. 2014, for Bd: O'Hanlon et al. 2018). While Bd can cause disease in frogs, salamanders and caecilians, Bsal has only been reported to cause disease in salamanders and newts, although the pathogen has been detected in some frog species (Martel et al. 2013). Bd has spread globally, but at present, Bsal is only known in Asia and has been introduced to Europe, most likely through the pet trade in salamanders (Martel et al. 2014, Nguyen et al. 2017). Currently in Europe, Bsal has been detected in the wild in the Netherlands, Belgium, Germany (e.g. Thein et al. 2020) and Spain (Martel et al. 2020), and has been shown to be highly pathogenic to most urodelan taxa in Europe (Martel et al. 2014). Laboratory trials for susceptibility to Bsal found this species to be highly susceptible to the disease (Gilbert et al. 2020, A. Martels and F. Pasmans pers. comm. September 2021). Based on current distribution data for Bsal, it is expected that the natural advancement of the infection could be up to 10 km per year which would result in a conservative advancement of 400–500 km per 50 years. Extinction risk modelling demonstrates that this species would be at significant risk from the natural spread of the fungus in the next 50 years, and could be categorised under Endangered or Vulnerable under criterion E if it was found in mainland Europe. However, this is an island species and Sardinia currently has no records of Bsal. This does not take into consideration the human-induced introduction of the disease, and should a new outbreak occur on Sardinia then it will need to be reassessed as soon as possible as this is a very plausible future threat.
UseTradeDocumentation.value: This species is found in the pet trade; collection from the wild for trade is thought to be slightly affecting the population (G. Tessa pers. comm. September 2019).

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation in Place
This species is protected by national legislation and is present in Natura 2000 protected areas on both Sardinia and on Corsica. It is listed in Appendix II of the Bern Convention and is listed on Annex IV of the EU Habitats Directive. The species is considered NT (A2e) in the Italian Red List Status (Rondinini et al. 2022), however, the available data do not support this Category (D. Savi pers. comm. 2022). It is assessed as Least Concern in France (UICN France et al. 2015).

Conservation needed
Long term monitoring of population. Increase of size of specific protected areas.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: This species is found within the vicinity of pools, ponds and streams, usually in woody areas. In residential areas, they can be found in gardens, as long as there is nearby water. It reproduces in springs, cisterns and other suitable waterbodies, by larval development.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative:
The Sardinian Tree Frog is quite widespread and common on Corsica. The subpopulations on the smaller islets are subject to fluctuations in size related to the temporary character of the breeding sites. Surveys carried out throughout the species' range (Sardinia and Corsica) in 2019, did not show evidence of significant declines in sites of occurrence or demographic size, as compared to a similar survey in 2010-2011 (D. Canestrelli pers. comm. February 2020). From surveys in 2018 and 2019, the species is still being recorded in good numbers (D. Canestrelli and D. Salvi pers. comm. October 2019).

The Italian subpopulations are considered to be relatively stable; according to Rondinini et al. (2013), Italian subpopulations experienced a decline of 20-25% in the previous 10 years, however, a widespread decline in the last decade (2012-2022) is not supported by field observations (D. Salvi and L. Vignoli pers. comm. 2022). In many localities, strong fluctuations from one year to another were observed but not a declining trend (D. Salvi pers. comm. 2022). The species is quite common and inhabits almost every waterbody (both natural and artificial, also in urbanised areas like camping areas) that have been sampled in Sardinia (L. Vignoli pers. comm. 2022).
RangeDocumentation.narrative: This species is restricted to central Mediterranean islands. In France, it occurs on Corsica and Cavallo Island (between Corsica and Sardinia). In Italy, the species occurs on Sardinia and on some islands in the La Maddalena Archipelago (Sant’Antioco, San Pietro and Asinara), and on Elba and Capraia in the Tuscan Archipelago. It occurs from sea level to 1,743 m asl on Corsica.
RedListRationale.value: The Sardinian Tree Frog is endemic to Europe. It is assessed as Least Concern in view of its relatively wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification and presumed large population.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
This species is not considered to be majorly threatened and utilises artificial waterbodies for reproduction (D. Salvi pers. comm. October 2019).

Rondinini et al. (2013) reported declines (prior to 2013) as a result of water collection for agriculture and habitat loss (loss of wetlands in agricultural areas, the building of new roads, water abstraction for use by people and agriculture purposes, drying out of artificial waterbodies). Urbanisation was reported as a threat in the 2008 assessment, however, this was incorrect and is not considered to be a threat within its' range (D. Canestrelli pers. comm. February 2020).

Di Nicola and Ferrer (2022) reported the first observed occurrence of predation by the invasive water frog Pelophylax sp., however, further research is required to understand the significance of this threat.
UseTradeDocumentation.value: There are no records of this species being utilised.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is present in Doñana and Sierra Nevada National Parks in Spain. It is listed on Appendix III of the Convention on the Conservation of European Wildlife and Natural Habitats (Bern Convention). It was listed in the Regional Catalogue of Andalucía (Reques et al. 2006), and as DD in the Spanish Red List (Pleguezuelos et al. 2002).

Research Needed
Population monitoring is required.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: This species can be found in dry or slightly damp open habitats including open woods, shrubland, salt marshes, and cultivated areas. It can survive in intensively farmed areas and is present in some modified habitats (such as non-intensively farmed fields). It breeds after rain in shallow sunny ponds (up to 1.5 m deep), lagoons, stream backwaters, drains, roadside ditches, and possibly in salt marshes.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: It is considered to be scarce in Portugal, and is locally abundant in suitable habitat in Spain. It is increasing in Doñana in Spain, but a 30% decline is thought to have occurred in the Andalucía region between 1993-2006 (Tejedo et al. 2003, Reques et al. 2006), and the easternmost subpopulations in Spain in the provinces of Málaga and Granada are isolated and under threat (R. Reques to I. Martínez-Solano pers. comm. April 2020). Overall, due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, the population is inferred to be decreasing.
RangeDocumentation.narrative: This species is endemic to southeastern Portugal and southern Spain (Barbadillo et al. 1999, Sánchez-Herráiz et al. 2000, Ferrand de Almeida et al. 2001, Arnold 2003, García-Cardenete et al. 2003, Malkmus 2004) however, further investigation into the range of this species is needed in Portugal. It is present from sea level up to approximately 1,450 m asl in Granada province, Spain.
RedListRationale.value: The Iberian Parsley Frog is endemic to the Iberian peninsula, Europe. The species is listed as Least Concern in view of its relatively wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification and presumed large population.
ThreatsDocumentation.value: Loss of suitable freshwater breeding habitats (including stream channelisation) is a threat as it causes habitat fragmentation. Predation of larvae and adults by exotic fish and the introduction of Louisiana Crayfish (Procambarus clarkii) are also threats.
UseTradeDocumentation.value: There are no records of this species being utilised.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
Although it occurs in many protected areas, several are not well protected or managed for biodiversity conservation. The species is listed on Annex V of the EU Habitats Directive (92/43/EEC) and Appendix III of the Bern Convention.

Conservation Needed
Improved management of the protected areas where this species occurs is required.

Research Needed
Further research into the population status and distribution of this species is urgently needed.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative:
This species is associated with both permanent and temporary wetlands, including slow-moving rivers and streams, lakes, ponds and marshes, artificial drainage channels, reservoirs and tanks, and wastewater oxidation tanks. Breeding and larval development presumably take place in these waterbodies.

A continuing decline in habitat quality is inferred from the known threats.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: It does not appear to be particularly abundant and is especially difficult to find in dry years. Where waterbodies are permanent, the species is more common. A declining population trend is suspected, but it is not known whether there is continuing decline in mature individuals.
RangeDocumentation.narrative: The Cretan Frog (Pelophylax cretensis) is endemic to the island of Crete, Greece (Arnold 2003, Pafilis and Maragou 2020), where it is patchily distributed over a wide area up to 920 m asl (with one unconfirmed record at 1,330 m asl) (Moravec and Lymberakis 2022). It occurs in ten or fewer threat-defined locations, and its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 14,100 km2.
RedListRationale.value: The Cretan Frog (Pelophylax cretensis) is endemic to the Greek island of Crete. It is assessed as Endangered under the criterion B2ab(iii) because its area of occupancy (AOO) is approximately 432 km2, it is present in less than 10 threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
Major threats to the species are the degradation and destruction of habitat due to human activities (fire, residential, industrial, and tourism development, groundwater pumping, livestock farming, agriculture) and agrochemical pollution. Extraction of stream water in the uplands for agricultural irrigation leaves many lowlands dry during the summer months.

Other significant threats to local subpopulations are the introduction of alien species (e.g., the American Bullfrog, Aquabana catesbeiana), and collection for scientific and research purposes. Its limited distribution increases its vulnerability (Sotiropoulos 2010, Sotiropoulos and Lymberakis 2015).
UseTradeDocumentation.value: There are no records of this species being utilised.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati: This species is presumed to occur in several protected areas. It is listed on Annex IV of the EU Natural Habitats Directive and on Appendix II of the Bern Convention, and it is protected by national legislation.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: This is a mostly montane species associated with fast-flowing streams that have a rocky substrate and some vegetation. It may also be found in small ponds or mountain peat bogs, but it is not known if it can adapt to habitat modification. This species breeds in wetland habitats.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: The species is is quite common. Its population trend is unknown, but it is considered to be fine in Italy (F. Ficetola and R. Manenti pers. comm. September 2019).
RangeDocumentation.narrative: This species is endemic to Europe, where it is restricted to the Apennine Mountains and other hilly areas of Italy (and San Marino), south of the Po Valley. It is generally found at elevations ranging between 100-1,000 m asl.
RedListRationale.value:
Global and European regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)
EU 27 regional assessment: Least Concern (LC)

This European endemic species is assessed as Least Concern globally and for the EU27 member states in view of its wide distribution and presumed large population.
ThreatsDocumentation.value: The main threats to this species are the loss of stream habitats and aquatic pollution presumably through agriculture and urbanisation.
UseTradeDocumentation.value: There are no records of this species being utilised.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is listed on Appendix III of the Bern Convention. It occurs in several protected areas. The species is assessed as Near Threatened for the France national Red List (UICN France et al. 2015).

Conservation Needed
There is an urgent need for an EU (European Union) wide coordinated approach and implementation of the Bsal Action Plan by Gilbert et al. (2020), which was commissioned by the European Commission.

Research Needed
If an outbreak of Bsal was to occur within this species' range, population monitoring would need to be implemented immediately and this species may need to be reassessed.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative:
This species occupies mainly temperate and supra-Mediterranean deciduous forests composed of Beech and Chestnut, and meso-/oro-Mediterranean forests of Black Pine and Holm Oak, from 240 to 1,722 m asl; it also occurs in meso-Mediterranean sclerophyllous shrubland (from 139 to 215 m asl) but is absent from highly modified habitats, such as intensive agriculture and suburban habitats, where the vegetation structure does not resemble natural forest formations (Escoriza and Hernandez 2019). Salvi et al. (2016) demonstrates the close association between the evolutionary and demographic history of this species and the changes in temperate forest ranges. Escoriza and Hernandez (2021) suggested that the species depends on the maintenance of densely vegetated and topographically complex habitats, which reduce temperature fluctuations and highlighted the importance of natural vegetal cover in the conservation of subpopulations of this salamander.

This species gives birth to well-developed larvae that complete metamorphosis in streams, ponds and other water bodies; fully metamorphosed young are occasionally produced.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: It is common in suitable habitat. Its population is considered to be relatively stable.
RangeDocumentation.narrative: This European species is endemic to the island of Corsica, France (Gasc et al. 1997, Delaugerre and Cheylan 1992), where it is widespread throughout the island from the south towards the extreme north (Cap Corse, e.g. Pietracorbara and Luri; U. Schulte pers. comm. November 2022). Distribution gaps can be found in the region of Bonifacio and the Plaine Orientale. It is found between 50–1,750 m asl, but is more common between 500–1,300 m asl. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 5,489 km2.
RedListRationale.value: This European endemic is listed as Least Concern since, although its extent of occurrence is 5,489 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in an area of extensive, suitable habitat which appears not to be under significant threat, it has a presumed large population, and it is unlikely to be declining fast enough to qualify for listing in a threatened category.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
The main threats to this species are loss of woodland habitat (especially as a result of forest fires), prolonged drought as a result of climate change, and pollution from agricultural and domestic sources. However, it is not believed to be significantly at risk.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is protected by law in several provinces in Italy, and it is listed in Appendix II of the Bern Convention and in Annex II and IV of the Habitats Directive. It occurs in several protected areas, including most national parks in southern Italy.

Conservation Needed
There is an urgent need for a EU (European Union) wide coordinated approach and implementation of the Bsal Action Plan by Gilbert et al. (2020), which was commissioned by the European Commission.

Research Needed
If an outbreak of Bsal was to occur within this species' range, population monitoring would need to be carried out immediately and this species would need to be reassessed.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: This species is mainly found in forests with dense undergrowth in hilly and mountainous areas. Only females of this species are aquatic during the short oviposition phase, for which well-oxygenated waters, slow-running streams (usually with rocky beds), drinking troughs and residual pools in stream beds are used. It appears to avoid seriously modified habitats. Little information is available on the ecology and reproductive biology of this species.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: It is common in suitable habitat, and at some localities it can be abundant (A. Romano pers. comm. September 2019). Its population is suspected to be stable at present.
RangeDocumentation.narrative: This species is endemic to southern peninsular Italy in the Apennine Mountains (where it is widespread) and other hilly areas, south of Caserta province (Campania region) along the Tyrrhenian slope and south of the Daunia Apennines along the Adriatic slope. North of this it is replaced by Salamandrina perspicillata. It is usually found at elevations between 200 and 900 m asl, but can occur between 50–1,555 m asl (A. Romano pers. comm. September 2019). The EOO is 50,434 km2; the AOO has not been estimated due to the lack of representative georeferenced locality data.
RedListRationale.value: This European endemic species is assessed as Least Concern in view of its relatively wide distribution, and presumed large and stable population.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
In parts of the species' range there are some localised declines through habitat loss and aquatic pollution. But overall, its habitat is not significantly threatened.

UseTradeDocumentation.value: It is occasionally traded illegally for the pet trade (A. Romano pers. comm. September 2019).

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species has been recorded from Parco Geominerario Storico e Ambientale della Sardegna and most of the range is within Monte Albo (ITB021107) Natura 2000 site (F. Ficetola and R. Manenti pers. comm. September 2019). It is listed on Appendix II and (as Hydromantes flavus) on Revised Annex I of Resolution 6 (1998; listing species requiring specific habitat conservation measures) of the Bern Convention and on Annexes II and IV (as a species in need of strict protection) of the EU Natural Habitats Directive. It was included in the Italian national Red List as Vulnerable (Rondinini et al. 2013).

Conservation Needed
Continued and improved management of protected areas is required for the conservation of this species. There is also an urgent need for an EU (European Union) wide coordinated approach and implementation of the Bsal Action Plan by Gilbert et al. (2020), which was commissioned by the European Commission.

Research Needed
Long-term population monitoring of this species is highly recommended (F. Ficetola pers.comm, October 2022). Further research should be carried out to understand the full impact of Bsal on this species. If an outbreak of Bsal was to occur within this species' range, population monitoring would need to be carried out immediately and this species will need to be reassessed.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: The species is found in damp mountain regions, rocky outcrops, caves, crevices, and forested areas. Its preferred habitat often has a good covering of damp moss. It reproduces through the direct development of a few terrestrial eggs.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: It is locally common within its limited range. At the lower elevations of its range, it is thought to be in greater decline due to habitat loss and degradation, but it is found in higher numbers in the higher elevations (above 500 m asl - with densities 10x greater in these areas; Lunghi et al. 2018).
RangeDocumentation.narrative: This European endemic species is endemic to the Monte Albo chain of northeastern Sardinia (Italy). It has been recorded between 40–1,050 m asl. It occurs in three to five threat defined locations, and its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 634 km<sup>2</sup>.
RedListRationale.value: This Italian endemic species is assessed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 110 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in five or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
There are localised threats of habitat loss occurring within this species' range. At lower elevations, habitat loss and degradation is caused by logging, urbanisation, and quarrying for limestone (Europe Red List Assessment Workshop September 2019). Disturbance caused by tourism is a localised but increasing threat in some caves, which may increase with the recent designation of a regional park, Tepilora, and littering is causing localised habitat degradation (F. Ficetola, R. Manenti and E. Lunghi pers. comm. September 2019). There are reports that this species has been illegally collected for the pet trade (E. Lunghi pers. comm. September 2019). Climate change is likely to be a major threat to this species in the future due to narrow microclimatic preferences of the genus, which will be problematic as the climate alters their distribution and activity (Ficetola et al. 2020).

This species has not been tested for its susceptibility to Bsal. However, it is presumed to be vulnerable to infection, given the susceptibility of closely related taxa, such as Speleomantes genei and S. strinatii which have been tested (Gilbert et al. 2020, F. Pasmans and A. Martel pers. comm. June 2021). However, this does not take into account human-induced introduction of the disease, and should a new outbreak occur on Sardinia then it will need to be reassessed as soon as possible as it is likely a future threat.
UseTradeDocumentation.value: There are reports that this species has been illegally collected for the pet trade (E. Lunghi pers. comm. September 2019).

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
The species is listed on Appendix II of the Bern Convention, is listed on Annex IV of the EU Natural Habitats Directive an included in the National Red List. Conservation Needed
Continued and improved management of protected areas is required for the conservation of this species. There is also an urgent need for an EU (European Union) wide coordinated approach and implementation of the Bsal Action Plan by Gilbert et al. Appropriate management of ancient mining sites and caves, making them inaccessible to visitors but available for animal species (including cave salamanders) to enter.

PopulationDocumentation.narrative: The species was considered to have been generally common within its limited range since the 1980s, being only relatively uncommon within the Carbonia-Barbusi-Monte Tasua area (Gasc et al. 1997). It is thought to have declined in the last 10–20 years and is no longer considered to be common, although it has been recorded in surveys in 2011, 2013 and 2015 (Europe Red List Assessment Workshop September 2019). It is thought that the species has disappeared from the Carbonia-Barbusi-Monte Tasua area due to the decline in the water table level caused by mineral extraction (A. Romano pers. comm. October 2022) that is occurring within the species' range, which has caused a drastic reduction in humidity of the previously suitable terrestrial habitats (Europe Red List Assessment Workshop September 2019). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat and the collection of individuals for the pet trade, the population is inferred to be decreasing.
RangeDocumentation.narrative: This European species is endemic to the region of Sulcis-Iglesiente in southwestern Sardinia, Italy, between 8–650 m asl. Its occurs in at least five to ten threat-defined locations, and its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,253 km<sup>2</sup>. The area of occupancy (AOO) has not been estimated due to the absence of representative, expert-reviewed locality data.
RedListRationale.value: This European endemic species is assessed as Vulnerable because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,253 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in ten or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
The major threat to this species is general deforestation of suitable habitat caused by logging (which is also changing the microclimate of cave habitats), mineral extraction, urbanisation, and the illegal harvesting of this species (F. Ficetola, R. Manenti and E. Lunghi pers. comm. September 2019). Climate change is likely to be a major threat to this species due to narrow microclimatic preferences of the genus, which will be problematic as the climate alters their distribution and activity (Ficetola et al. 2020). The other important threat is inappropriate closing of ancient mining sites and human-made caves without possibility for these salamanders to move outside and inside.

However, this does not take into account human-induced introduction of the disease, and should a new outbreak occur on Sardinia then it will need to be reassessed as soon as possible as it is likely a future threat.
UseTradeDocumentation.value: There are reports that this species has been illegally collected for the pet trade (E. Lunghi pers. comm. September 2019).

Conservation Actions In-Place
This species has been recorded from Parco Nazionale Gennargentu e Golfo di Orosei and four Natura 2000 sites in Italy, and it is likely to occur in Parco Naturale Regionala della Giara di Gesturi. HabitatDocumentation.narrative: This species is found in humid rocky outcrops, caves, crevices, and forested areas in the vicinity of streams. It cannot tolerate a lot of habitat disturbance (F. ThreatsDocumentation.value:
General localised habitat loss caused by human-induced fires to clear the land for pasture and housing is the major threat to this species in Italy (F. Ficetola, R. Manenti and E. Lunghi pers. comm. September 2019). It is also thought to be threatened by overharvesting for the pet trade (F. Ficetola, R. Manenti and E. Lunghi pers. comm. September 2019). Lunghi pers. comm. October 2021).

Bd has spread globally, but at present Bsal is only known in Asia and has been introduced to Europe, most likely through the pet trade in salamanders (Martel et al. 2014, Nguyen et al. 2017). ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species has been recorded from the Parco Naturale Regionale “Sette Fratelli-Monte Genas”. It is considered Critically Endangered in the National Red List of Vertebrates of Italy (Rondinini et al. 2022). Societas Europaea Herpetologica granted funds for the monitoring of this species in 2022 (https://www.seh-herpetology.org/seh-grants/seh-grants-2022)

Conservation Needed
Continued habitat management for the cavity closure to tourism is required in order to reduce the risk of disease introduction and disturbance. There is also an urgent need for an EU (European Union) wide coordinated approach and implementation of the Bsal Action Plan by Gilbert et al. (2020), which was commissioned by the European Commission.

Research Needed
Further research is required to determine what has caused the major decline in the population. Research should also be carried out to understand the full impact of Bsal on this species. If an outbreak of Bsal was to occur within this species' range, population monitoring would need to be carried out immediately and this species may need to be reassessed. Long-term monitoring of subpopulations is necessary to avoid future population decline (F. Ficetola pers.comm. October 2022).
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: This species is found in a granitic, almost caveless area, in humid rocky outcrops, crevices, and forested areas. It reproduces through the direct development of a few terrestrial eggs.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: It is locally common, but it is difficult to find due to its secretive nature. Surveys between 2015–2018 in Sette Fratelli in this species' range observed a decline (R. Cogoni pers. comm. September 2019) with the observation of one or two dead individuals (F. Ficetola pers. comm. August 2021), although the causes of this are unknown. Monitoring at this locality was interrupted due to the COVID-19 pandemic, however, a visit in 2021 found a large number of dead individuals and very few living individuals (F. Ficetola and E. Lunghi pers. comm. August 2021). It is estimated that 80–90% of the global population existed in this locality, and that there has been at least a ca. 70% decline overall in the entire known population, possibly even an 80% decline, although this is less certain at this time (F. Ficetola and R. Cognoni pers. comm. August 2021). The reason for this decline is unknown; it was speculated that it could be due to a pathogen, a pollution event or an extreme climatic event (F. Ficetola pers. comm. October 2021). Laboratory analyses did not confirmed presence of Bsal in dead animals (A. Romano pers. comm.), however, presence of Bd was detected in several Disscoglossus individuals at less than 1 km distance from the nearest S. sarrabusensis subpopulation (T. Kirschey pers. comm.). While harvesting levels have decreased, it still may be a threat to the species.
RangeDocumentation.narrative: This European endemic species has an extremely small range in extreme south-eastern Sardinia, Italy. It is only known from the general vicinity of Monte dei Sette Fratelli, between approximately 200–850 m asl, in the territory known as Sarrabus in the province of Cagliari (roughly between 39°15' N and 39°12' N). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 70 km<sup>2</sup>. The area of occupancy (AOO) has not been estimated but is likely to be similarly restricted.
RedListRationale.value: The Sette Fratelli Cave Salamander (Speleomantes sarrabusensis) is endemic to Europe, where it is restricted to a small region of Sardinia, Italy. The species is assessed as Critically Endangered (A2a; B1ab(v)) because of an observed population decline, suspected to be up to 80% over the past three generation lengths (15–30 years) due to either a pathogen, a pollution event or an extreme climatic event. This species' extent of occurrence (EOO) is 70 km2, it is considered to occur in one threat-defined location, and there is continuing decline in the number of mature individuals due to harvesting. The inclusion of criterion A is precautionary as the exact rate of reduction is not known, but is thought to be very significant and an 80% reduction is considered plausible.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
The only known subpopulation is in a protected area, so there are no major threats to the habitat. However, the species is intrinsically at risk because of its tiny range and harvesting for the pet trade may still be a threat. Logging (which is performed by a public authority) is considered to be a minor threat to this species, and disturbance caused by tourism may be a threat (F. Ficetola, R. Manenti and E. Lunghi pers. comm. September 2019). The reason for the decline in Sette Fratelli is unknown, and urgently requires further investigation (F. Ficetola, R. Manenti and E. Lunghi pers. comm. September 2019). Climate change is likely to be a major threat to this species due to narrow microclimatic preferences of the genus, which will be problematic as the climate alters their distribution and activity (Ficetola et al. 2020).

Ficetola and E. Lunghi pers. comm. October 2021). While it may not be collected at the same level, it is still thought to be a risk for the species.

The species occurs in Parco Nazionale Gennargentu e Golfo di Orosei, and at least two Natura 2000 sites (F. Ficetola and R. Manenti pers. comm. September 2019). It is listed on Appendix II of the Bern Convention, and it is also listed on Annexes II and IV of the EU Natural Habitats Directive. It was considered VU D2 in the National Red List of Vertebrates of Italy (Rondinini et al. 2022).

Conservation Needed

There is also an urgent need for an EU (European Union) wide coordinated approach and implementation of the Bsal Action Plan by Gilbert et al. (2020), which was commissioned by the European Commission.

Research Needed
It would be good to understand what is causing the recent declines in this species. Further research should also be carried out to understand the full impact of Bsal on this species. HabitatDocumentation.narrative: The species is found in humid rocky outcrops, limestone caves, crevices, and forested areas with a good growth of moss in the vicinity of streams. It reproduces through the direct development of a few terrestrial eggs.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: Although the species has often been considered to be common, and even abundant, within suitable habitats (with recorded densities of as much as 300 animals per ha in some areas; Vosenek et al. 1987), it appears to have undergone declines and has become more difficult to observe in its limited range (R. Lecis pers. comm. 2008; F. Ficetola, R. Manenti and E. Lunghi pers. comm. September 2019). The reasons for the declines are unknown but, due to the ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, the population is inferred to continue to be decreasing.

RedListRationale.value: This European endemic species is assessed as Endangered because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 708 km<sup>2</sup>, it is known from five or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is observed continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat and the number of mature individuals due to over-harvesting.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:

Disturbance caused by tourism is a localised threat in some caves, and it may also be sensitive to over-collection for the pet trade, particularly from some of its cave habitats which are easier to access (F. Ficetola, R. Manenti and E. Lunghi pers. comm. September 2019). ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is listed on Appendix III of the Bern Convention. It is listed in regional Red Data Books and is present in the protected areas of Parque Nacional de Sierra Nevada, Parque Natural Sierra de Baza, Parque Natural Sierra de Castril, Parque Natural Sierra de Huétor, Parque Natural Sierra Tejeda y Almijara and Parque Natural of de Cazorla, Segura y las Villas. Protection measures in Castilla-La Mancha, Andalusia, such as restoration and construction of new breeding habitats, are under way. There is also a conservation program focusing on mitigating chytridiomycosis in Andalucía, where there are captive populations for ex situ conservation programs. A pilot disinfection program for chytridiomycosis is underway by the regional government of Andalucía (J. Bosch pers. comm. November 2019), with the same measure that were utilised for Alytes muletensis (e.g. habitat disinfection- see Bosch et al. 2015).

Conservation Needed
Continued maintenance of efforts to tackle chytridiomycosis are necessary for the conservation of this species.

Research Needed
Population monitoring is required.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative:
The species is present in pine and oak forests, most often on calciferous substrate, in open, very rocky landscapes. Adults occur in rock fissures and on stones next to water sources. Reproduction and larval development takes place in permanent mountain streams, man-made reservoirs and cattle troughs, and the larvae may take a long time to mature. Almost all known breeding habitats are human-modified water bodies.

Based on its congener Alytes obstetricans, which occurs in similar habitats, the generation length for this species is estimated to be seven years.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: Subpopulations of this species are very fragmented, many of them confined to isolated mountains and valleys. It is relatively common in the Alcaraz, Segura, and Cazorla mountains, but it is rare in drier mountains (Filabres, Baza, Gádor), where it is associated with springs. Subpopulations in drier areas can consist of only a few adults. In the last 10 years, several subpopulations have declined which is very likely due to chytridiomycosis (J. Bosch pers. comm. November 2019). Declines have been observed in over 109 breeding localities across the entire area of distribution (per province: Almería 52, Granada 33, Jaén 17, Málaga 7), which were visited in both 2010 and 2020 (J. Bosch and E. González-Miras pers. comm. May 2021). It is estimated that in this time period that 63.8% of the population has declined, and it is thought that chytridiomycosis has impacted the most susceptible subpopulations (J. Bosch pers. comm. July 2021). While this species can breed in some anthropogenic habitats, due to ongoing decline in the quality and extent of its habitat, the population is inferred to be decreasing.
RangeDocumentation.narrative: This species is restricted to the mountains of southeastern Spain. It occurs between 700–2,510 m asl (Sierra Nevada, Almería). Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 36,748 km<sup>2</sup>.
RedListRationale.value: This species is endemic to the mountains of southeastern Spain. It is assessed as Endangered because of an observed population decline, thought to be more than 50% over the past 21 years (which represents three generation lengths - the decline is specific to 2010–2020), inferred from the impact of chytridiomycosis on this species.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
The species is threatened by loss of suitable breeding habitat as a result of excessive water withdrawal, droughts, and modernisation of agricultural practices leading to the abandonment of cattle troughs and other man-made water sources. Subpopulations are highly fragmented, with low levels of gene flow (Dias et al. 2015). This species is highly susceptible to the disease chytridiomycosis (Bosch et al. 2013), and several subpopulations have recently disappeared. Batrachochytrium dendrobatidis (Bd) was confirmed at just three localities across the entire species' range in 2011, however, it is now present throughout and Bd prevalence has increased by 30–50% during the last decade (Thumsová et al. 2021). The spread is believed to have been facilitated from the original infected subpopulations, the introduction of infective amphibian hosts into unaffected breeding sites of this species and other anthropogenic pressures (Thumsová et al. 2021).

Species distribution modelling projects >70% potential range contraction for the period 2041–2070 using climatic variables (Araújo et al. 2011), and climate change will likely be an increasing problem in the future.
UseTradeDocumentation.value: There are no records of this species being utilised.
