HabitatDocumentation.narrative:
The aquatic habitats of this species are exclusively unpolluted small rivers, mountain rivers and lakes; it is most often found in calm sections where there is a high-water level. The terrestrial habitats of the species are generally open riverine macchia or woodland. It is not considered to be very adaptable to changes in habitat.

It breeds in water, with approximately 70 eggs laid in groups under rocks (Thiesmeier et al. 1996).
PopulationDocumentation.narrative:
This species is very common in suitable habitat, mostly between 600–1,500 m asl. It is considered to have a relatively stable population trend at present.

RangeDocumentation.narrative: This species is endemic to the island of Corsica, France (Gasc et al. 1997, Arnold 2003, Carranza and Amat 2005, Bisconti et al. 2013). It ranges from near Oletta in the north to Montagne de Cagna in the south, and from San Guillano in the east to Golfe de Girolata in the west. It occurs from near sea level to 2,260 m asl. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 9,791 km2. The area of occupancy (AOO) is c.1,000 km2, but the species occurs in many more than ten threat-defined locations.
RedListRationale.value: The Corsican Mountain Newt (Euproctus montanus) is a European endemic species. It is assessed as Least Concern since, although its extent of occurrence (EOO) and area of occupancy (AOO) are restricted, it is common with a presumed large and stable population.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
Threats to this species include habitat fragmentation, the introduction of predatory fishes (eg. trout) to streams, water pollution, and the over extraction of water for both agriculture and tourism. However, it is not believed to be significantly threatened at present.

This species is probably present in several Natural Parks in southwest Portugal (I. Martínez-Solano pers. comm. December 2021).

Conservation Needed

HabitatDocumentation.narrative:
The species occupies a diverse range of terrestrial habitats including eucalyptus plantations, pine groves, open oak (Quercus) woodland, scrub and sandy coastal areas. Its habitat preferences can be inferred from its congener, Lissotriton boscai. It is a largely aquatic species, with vegetated shallow ponds and streams being the preferred habitat. The importance of lotic aquatic sites for this species was demonstrated by de Vries and Marco (2017). It may also be found in cattle troughs, lagoons, streams and deep still waters, and is frequently found in temporary ponds. The species may be found in traditionally farmed areas.

While it is tolerant to a degree of habitat disturbance, it is sensitive to habitat disturbance and loss (Teixeira 2008). It is presumed to breed by larval development, as with its congeners.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: Teixeira (2008) considered this species to be relatively common. Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, the population is inferred to be decreasing.
RangeDocumentation.narrative: This species is endemic to southwestern Portugal, between 0–900 m asl (Teixeira 2008). It is not expected to occur much more widely; the range is largely well delineated at the broad scale, although some parts of the contact zone with Lissotriton boscai need to be finely delineated with molecular markers (I. Martínez-Solano pers. comm. December 2021).
RedListRationale.value: The Portuguese Smooth Newt (Lissotriton maltzani) is endemic to Europe, where it is restricted to southwestern Portugal. It is assessed as Least Concern in view of its wide distribution, tolerance of a degree of habitat modification and presumed large population.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
The species is mostly threatened by the loss of breeding pools caused by drainage for agriculture and urbanisation. Large-scale changes in land use associated with agriculture have been associated with population declines in co-distributed amphibian species and are likely to play a role with this species too (Beja and Alcazar 2003). Predation by introduced fish and other introduced species (such as crayfish [Procambarus clarkii] and mink [Neovison vison]) is also a threat. It is also likely to be collected for the pet trade, but it is not thought to constitute a major threat.

Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans (Bsal) is an emerging fungal pathogen affecting amphibians and is closely related to B. dendrobatidis (Bd), which has had a devastating impact on amphibian populations around the world. Both pathogens cause the infectious disease chytridiomycosis, and both are believed to have originated in Asia (for Bsal: Martel et al. 2014, for Bd: O'Hanlon et al. 2018). While Bd can cause disease in frogs, salamanders and caecilians, Bsal has only been reported to cause disease in salamanders and newts, although the pathogen has been detected in some frog species (Martel et al. 2013). Bd has spread globally, but at present Bsal is only known in Asia and has been introduced to Europe, most likely through the pet trade in salamanders (Martel et al. 2014, Nguyen et al. 2017). Currently in Europe, Bsal has been detected in the wild in the Netherlands, Belgium, Germany (e.g. Thein et al. 2020) and Spain (Martel et al. 2020), and has been shown to be highly pathogenic to most urodelan taxa in Europe (Martel et al. 2014). Laboratory trials for susceptibility to Bsal have demonstrated that Lissotriton boscai is moderately susceptible to infection (Gilbert et al. 2020), however, it is thought that it may only suffer from low mortality rates as only one in five individuals died from low dosages (F. Pasmans and A. Martel pers. comm. June 2021), and it is likely that Lissotriton maltzani is similarly susceptible. While there is no Bsal currently known to be present within its' range, although it is present in neighbouring Spain, this could be considered a potential threat to this species and it may need to be reassessed if the fungus is detected closer.
UseTradeDocumentation.value: It is probably collected for the pet trade, but it is not thought to constitute a major threat (I. Martínez-Solano pers. comm. December 2021).

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in some protected areas. It was considered Near Threatened in the 2009 National Red List, while the subpopulation from Kasos island was assessed as Critically Endangered (Legakis and Maragou 2009).

Conservation Needed
There is an urgent need for an EU (European Union) wide coordinated approach and implementation of the Bsal Action Plan by Gilbert et al. (2020), which was commissioned by the European Commission.

Research Needed
There is a need for close monitoring of the population status of this species for the effects of climate change and disease. If an outbreak of Bsal was to occur within this species' range, this species would need to be reassessed immediately.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: The Karpathos Salamander lives in Mediterranean rocky shrubby vegetation, karstic limestone boulder fields, and near human settlements where it inhabits loose rock walls and ruins. The species is nocturnal, and is more active during the night when there is high humidity. It is viviparous, giving birth to fully developed young on land, and it is not associated with water. Foraging involves invertebrates such as snails, worms and insects.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: This is considered a common species on Karpathos, while on Kasos it is considered quite rare (K. Sotiropoulos pers. comm. April 2018) and this subpopulation is declining (Elefterakos et al. 2007). While not majorly threatened at present, due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, the population is inferred to be locally declining. Based on observed low levels of heterozygosity and genetic polymorphism, it seems that this subpopulation experienced severe bottlenecks. Habitat fragmentation caused by overgrazing, climate change and human activities resulted in isolation and small size of local populations, increasing inbreeding (Elefterakos et al. 2007).
RangeDocumentation.narrative: This species is endemic to Greece, where it is restricted to the islands of Karpathos, Kasos and Saria in the southeast Aegean Sea (Eleftherakos et al. 2007). Its elevational range is unknown, but it is thought to occupy both low and higher elevations. Its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 1,056 km2, but could be as small as 628 km2 according to current data points from amphibian and reptile monitoring in Greece and GBIF (2023), and the AOO is just 88 km2 based on these data (E.-A. Toli pers. comm. 2023). On Kasos Island is quite rare and occurs in the northern part of the island only (Pafilis and Maragou 2020).
RedListRationale.value: This species is endemic to Europe, where it is restricted to three adjacent Greek islands in the Aegean Sea. The species is assessed as Vulnerable under criterion D2 because it is only known from three threat-defined locations and it is expected to be prone to the effects of climate change (droughts), and there is a risk of the salamander fungus Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans being introduced to the islands, which could drive the species to Critically Endangered or Extinct in a very short time in an uncertain future.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
No major threats are known, although local subpopulations might be affected by habitat loss. Declines on Kasos are thought to have been driven by the number of goats and extensive grazing (Eleftherakos et al. 2007), but the link seems indirect to population declines (P. Lymberakis pers. comm. October 2022). Kasos and Karpathos are both well-managed islands and little has changed over time (S. Bogaerts pers. comm. August 2021). Fires could be considered as a minor threat, however, this species lives mainly underground so may be less sensitive to this threat (F. Pasmans pers. comm. August 2021). Climate change might pose a threat, causing droughts and sea levels to rise in the future, although the latter effect would only be a risk to those subpopulations found at lower elevations (S. Bogaerts and F. Pasmans pers. comm. August 2021).

Batrachochytrium salamandrivorans (Bsal) is an emerging fungal pathogen affecting amphibians and is closely related to B. dendrobatidis (Bd), which has had a devastating impact on amphibian populations around the world. Laboratory trials for susceptibility to Bsal have demonstrated that the Karpathos Salamander is highly susceptible to infection, and 100% mortality was observed in the few individuals that were tested (Gilbert et al. 2020; F. Pasmans and A. Martel pers. comm. June 2021). While there is no Bsal currently known to be present within this species' range, it could be considered a potential major threat to this species. If an outbreak was to occur within its range then it will need to be reassessed as soon as possible, although its island distribution makes it unlikely that Bsal will rapidly spread across all subpopulations on all islands at one time (S. Bogaerts pers. comm. August 2021).
UseTradeDocumentation.value: In the 2009 Greek national Red List assessment (Legakis and Maragou 2009) it was reported that this species was collected for the international pet trade, however, there is no evidence for this and it is not thought to occurring at present (S. Bogaerts and F. Pasmans pers. comm. August 2021).

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
The species is listed on Annex V of the Habitats Directive (92/43/EEC) and Appendix III of the Bern Convention. In 2015, 10 adult individuals were translocated from Argoni to Olympos (Karpathos) to assist the establishment of the subpopulation in that locality, as part of the "Conservation and study of the biology of the Karpathos Frog, the most endangered and unknown amphibian in Europe" program (The Mohamed bin Zayed Species Conservation Fund). The "National Action Plan for the endemic Karpathos frog Pelophylax cerigensis" (GREEN FUND) is being implemented since 2020. Among its actions was the clarification of the phylogenetic relationship between the species’ population on Karpathos Island and the population of P. cf. bedriagae from the neighbouring island of Rhodes. Complete mitogenome analysis showed that individuals from Karpathos and Rhodes form a well-supported monophyletic group with low genetic distance between them (p-distance=0.1%). Hence, the Rhodes populations seem to belong to P. cerigensis and not to P. bedriagae as formerly thought, highlighting the need for revision of P. cerigensis current conservation status (Toli et al 2023). Another action recently implemented is the creation of six new artificial ponds and the management of the existing ones in order to assist the Karpathos populations during the dry months.

Conservation Needed
Continuation of monitoring, effective protection and appropriate management of the sites at which it is known to occur is necessary. Contrary to the high homogeneity of the two populations in the mitochondrial genome, subsequent analyses of genotypic data from ten microsatellite markers (Giannopoulou et al. 2023) revealed the existence of two distinct and highly differentiated gene pools, Karpathos and Rhodes, thus meeting the criteria to be characterised as distinct Management Units (MUs) (Moritz 1994). This should be considered when assessing the conservation status of the species, as well when planning targeted management actions.

Research Needed
Although the available information on the Karpathos population has increased during the past decade, further monitoring of the population and habitat quality trends is needed. In addition, thorough research of the aforementioned parameters, as well as the threats to the species would be essential for the newly acknowledged population of Rhodes Island.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: This is a mostly aquatic species that is largely restricted to permanent still or slow-running waters, and it will not tolerate habitat disturbance. Breeding and larval development presumably take place in these waterbodies.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: The population on Karpathos is considered to be relatively sparse (A. Christopoulos pers. comm. September 2023), although it is increasing due to a series of conservation actions implemented during the past decade. The same applies to the population on Rhodes, with the exception of two or three localities, where the species’ population seems to be denser (A. Christopoulos pers. comm. September 2023). Regarding the size and the trend of the Rhodes subpopulations, further research is needed, especially after the extensive wildfires that occurred on the island during July 2023.
RangeDocumentation.narrative: The Karpathos Frog (Pelophylax cerigensis) was formerly considered to be restricted to Karpathos Island, Greece, but recent research based on analyses of complete mitogenomes (Toli et al. 2023) found the species to also occur on Rhodes Island. On Karpathos it has a very restricted distribution (currently found in four localities within an area of less than 10 km2), whilst on Rhodes it appears to be more widespread. It can be found from sea level up to 500 m asl (point data from herpatlas.gr; Pafilis and Maragou 2020). Its area of occupancy (AOO) is estimated at 128 km2 and its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 2,835 km2.
RedListRationale.value: The Karpathos Frog (Pelophylax cerigensis) is endemic to Karpathos and Rhodes islands, Greece. It assessed as Endangered (EN), under the criteria B1ab(iii)+2ab(iii), because its Extent of Occurrence (EOO) is 2835 km2, its Area of Occupancy (AOO) is approximately 128 km2, it is present in between five and ten threat-defined locations, with five locations considered on a precautionary basis given the lack of knowledge about the scale and impact of recent wildfires on Rhodes. There is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
Regarding the Karpathos population, although the sites from which the species is known are fairly remote, even small, low-scale habitat changes could be detrimental to the species due to very small number of individuals. Freshwater habitats are subject to a number of threats such as excessive water abstraction, which is occurring for agricultural purposes including livestock watering. Water availability is or at least was the main threat. Even in winter, the volume of naturally available water is really limited in the original sites and dispersal to other water bodies across the island is probably problematic due to low reproductive output and limited connectivity. Fires are an additional potential threat, both from locals who use fire to manage their lands and wildfires, which may increase with drier conditions. The species may be vulnerable to climate change, although the effects are not fully understood at a local level at present. A further potential threat is the intensive collection for scientific and research purposes exacerbated by the limited and localised distribution of this species, although there have not been any recorded incidences of this yet. There is some subsistence agriculture (sheep and goat keeping) that is occurring on the island; however, this is actually considered to be beneficial to the species' population as goats do not allow the vegetation to become too dense and their droppings feed the insects that this species preys on.

Regarding the Rhodes subpopulation, further research is needed in order determine the specific threats to the species.
UseTradeDocumentation.value: There are no records of this species being utilised.

ConservationActionsDocumentation.narrati:
Conservation Actions In-Place
This species occurs in protected areas including Troodos National Forest Park and Cape Greco National Forest Park.

Conservation Needed
Improved habitat protection is required, including habitat restoration, and actions should be taken to regulate to manage the harvesting and trade of this species.

Research Needed
Further research is needed to accurately determine its distribution, population size and trends, life history and ecology to develop future conservation strategies in its natural habitats. In order to determine the relative stability of subpopulations, harvest, trade and habitat trends, long-term monitoring is required. Moreover, additional taxonomic research is necessary as all recently proclaimed Pelophylax species in the area hybridise what indicate that they may be conspecific and that it is premature to suggest taxonomic changes (J.Speybroeck pers. comm. October 2022, pointing on Speybroeck et al. 2020).
HabitatDocumentation.narrative:
This species occupies a wide range of habitats including wetlands, streams, small pools and ditches (Baier et al. 2009) in forest, shrubland and grassland habitats. It appears to be fairly tolerant of stagnant and fairly brackish water (Baier et al. 2009). Its call is described by Dufresnes (2019). It breeds by larval development, with its reproductive season occurring between March and June (Dufresnes 2019). Spawning takes place in stagnant water during the spring season each female lays compact egg masses that may contain up to 10,000 eggs in each clutch. Tadpoles remain in the water body until they metamorphose in the summer (https://www.herpatlas.cy).

It is generally 6–10 cm in size (Dufresnes 2019), and has been observed predating on aquatic and terrestrial insects, the mosquito fish (Gambusia affinis), and once on a bird nestling (Baier et al. 2009).
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: Its type locality, the Troodos area, as well as the vicinities of Nicosia City, has the highest population density (S.N. Litvinchuk pers. com. 2022). There is little hard data about its population trend, however, Cyprus is one of the European Union (EU) countries where frog leg (fresh, chilled or frozen) consumption is popular (Altherr et al. 2011). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat and likely harvesting for the frog leg trade, the population trend is inferred to be decreasing.
RangeDocumentation.narrative: This species is endemic to Cyprus, where it is widely distributed, occupying all suitable water bodies (rivers, reservoirs, dams). It is found in the Troodos area (type locality) in the western part of the island, the most humid region  of Cyprus (Plötner et al. 2012). In wide areas of the dry Mesaoria Plain in the central, eastern, and southeastern parts of the island, there are no records. Single subpopulations are often found around artificial water reservoirs and close to a few streams, especially in the Pediaios stream system. The lack of records in Northern part of Cyprus, particularly on the Karpas Peninsula, is likely due to sampling gaps. It occurs from sea level up to 1,700 m asl (https://www.herpatlas.cy). It occurs in 10 or fewer threat-defined locations, and its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 5,837 km2.
RedListRationale.value: This European endemic species is assessed as Vulnerable (VU B1ab(iii)) because its extent of occurrence (EOO) is 5,837 km<sup>2</sup>, it occurs in 10 or fewer threat-defined locations, and there is continuing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat.
ThreatsDocumentation.value: The species is threatened by the loss of habitat through the drainage of wetlands for agriculture and associated agricultural pollution, spraying the aquatic habitats for control of mosquitos (P. Lymberakis pers. comm. October 2022), excessive drought which is caused by climate change, and urbanisation and tourism development of coastal areas. It is likely to be threatened by harvest and trade in Cyprus. Also, possible import of other Pelophylax species for consumption (frog legs) could threaten native species due to unintentional release to the wild and possible hybridisation (D. Cogalniceanu pers. comm. October 2022), so import of any other Pelophylax species should not be recommended (P.A. Crochet, pers. comm. October 2022). Introduction of alien species (e.g. freshwater fish species) is very common in Cyprus and this also threatens P. cypriensis due to predation (P. Lymberakis pers. comm. October 2022)
UseTradeDocumentation.value: While not definitively confirmed, since Cyprus is one of the EU countries that imports frog legs (fresh, chilled or frozen) and its consumption is common in the country (Altherr et al. 2011), it is likely the species is harvested from the wild and traded.

Conservation Actions In-Place
This species is present in several protected areas, and it is listed on Annex IV of the EU Natural Habitats Directive and Appendix II of the Bern Convention.

Conservation Needed
Improved management of protected areas would be beneficial for the conservation of this species. There is also an urgent need for a EU (European Union) wide coordinated approach and implementation of the Bsal Action Plan by Gilbert et al. (2020), which was commissioned by the European Commission.

Research Needed
Further research is required on the effects of Bsal on adult individuals of this species to determine how much of a threat the fungus may be.
HabitatDocumentation.narrative: This species is often associated with woodland and agricultural habitats. It breeds in a variety of temporary ponds, ditches, slow-moving streams and lakes. It is not often found in modified habitats.
PopulationDocumentation.narrative: Although not necessarily abundant, this species is more common in southern areas, including the Basilicata and Calabrian mountains, and it is considered to be rare in central Italy, especially around the Italian Apennines. Declines have been observed in Calabria, Puglia and Abruzzo Mountains, especially in agricultural areas (C. Liuzzi pers. comm. September 2019). Due to ongoing decline in the extent and quality of its habitat, the population is inferred to be decreasing.
RangeDocumentation.narrative: This species is found through most of central and southern Italy, with higher concentrations at lower elevations. It has been recorded up to 1,750 m asl (C. Liuzzi pers. comm. September 2019).
RedListRationale.value: The Italian Newt (Lissotriton italicus) is a European endemic species that is restricted to southern peninsula Italy. It is assessed as Least Concern in view of its relatively wide distribution, presumed large population, and because it is unlikely to be declining fast enough for listing in a threatened category.
ThreatsDocumentation.value:
The main threats to the species are localised drainage of wetlands, the pollution and eutrophication of aquatic habitats (especially breeding ponds) which is caused by agriculture, and the introduction of predatory fishes.
